newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Nov 6.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - Nov 6.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Barangay officials said they are waging a nationwide campaign to amend the constitution. Officers of the Association of Barangay Councils said that barangay officials expect to complete the signature campaign for the proposed Charter changes by the end of November (TODAY)

- Immigration authorities barred two South African national from entering the country as part of the government's security measures for the coming Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meetings. The two, reportedly officers of the South African Agricultural Plantation and Allied Workers Union in Johannesburg, South Africa, were held for interrogation by immigration officials after anti-APEC leaflets were found in their possession. (MANILA TIMES)

- President Ramos said the inflation rate for October was pegged at 4.7 percent, much lower than the 5.5 percent projected by some economists. He expressed confidence that the lower-than-projected inflation rate will be sustained in the months ahead (PHILIPPINE STAR)

- Business groups were mildly surprised by the lower-than-expected October inflation rate. The Philippine Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PCCI) and the Federation of Philippine Industries (FPI) said the 4.7 percent only proved there is no reason for a mandated wage hike (BUSINESSWORLD)

- The Central Bank jacked up its overnight lending rate on Tuesday from 13 percent to 15 percent to quell speculations against the peso, said Central Bank Treasury Director Sergio Edeza. (THE BUSINESS DAILY)

- Petron Corp and the National Power Corp signed a 16 billion peso, two-year fuel supply pact on Tuesday. Petron will supply 4.4 billion liters of fuel oil and diesel to the power firm over a two-year period (MANILA BULLETIN).
